div1.p: Kerr reports on cooperation with the International Health Commission and discusses steps to be taken in eradication of malaria.

div1.head: Memorandum from John W. Kerr, September 20, 1915
div1.opener:
September 20, 1915.
MEMORANDUM relative to Investigations of Malaria in Co-
operation with the International Health Commission.
-----------------
div1.p:
In response to an invitation received from Mr. Wick-
liffe Rose, Director of the International Health Commission,
and in accordance with instructions from the Surgeon General,
a conference was had with the former today at the University
Club relative to the desirability and feasibility of anti-
malarial demonstrations being conducted by the Service in
cooperation with the International Health Commission.

In effect, Mr. Rose stated that during his travels
in this country and abroad on business relating to the
eradication of hookworm disease, it had been repeatedly
pointed out to him that there was as much, if not greater,
need of antimalarial measures as antihookworm measures.

In consequence, he had inquired into the work of
Rose, Celli, Koch, and particularly Watson, and had re-
viewed the literature relating to antimalarial work, and
was now of the opinion that the International Health Com-
mission might with advantage undertake some definite co-
operative work with the following specific objects in
view:

1. The treatment of malaria carriers after the method
-2-
advocated by Bass, in a selected area.

2. Demonstration work for the eradication of malaria
in a strictly rural section to be selected, using all prac-
tical means that it would be economical for like communi-
ties to adopt.

He proposed that the two lines of work should be car-
ried on simultaneously, the former in Mississippi under the
scientific supervision of Dr. Bass and the practical direc-
tion of Dr. Leathers; the latter to be conducted under the
supervision and direction of officers of the Public Health
Service aided by officers of the International Health Com-
mission. (It was not made clear whether these last mentioned
officers were to be appointed or selected from among those
now engaged in hookworm eradication work. It is believed,
however, that it was his intention that a portion or all
of the hookworm force should be utilized so as to eventual-
ly carry on both lines of work together.) Special empha-
sis was laid by Mr. Rose on the value of training officers
in antimalarial work, whose services would then be available
to the International Health Commission to carry on its anti-
malarial work in foreign countries should it seem desirable
to inaugurate such work on a large scale.

No mention was made by Mr. Rose of the amount of funds
that could be made available for cooperative work with the
Public Health Service. In fact, he stated that the matter
-3-
had not been formally considered by his Commission, and
that he would like to have a conference regarding details
before taking it up for formal action. It is understood he
had been informed that it was important to take up the mat-
ter with the Bureau before a conference with Dr. von Ezdorf
and other field officers was arranged for.

During our conference I informed Mr. Rose that it was
the policy of the Bureau to encourage State, municipal and
private initiative in public health work, and in so far as
possible, cooperate with these agencies to the end that
sanitation might be improved. I stated further that the
field for antimalarial activities is large, so large in
fact, that no single agency nor the federal government
could fully occupy it. At the same time emphasis was
laid on the importance of careful and unadvertised ex-
perimental work in order that demonstration work, par-
ticularly on the part of the federal government, would
not be retarded. The danger of the exploitation of
measurably successful results on a small scale was pointed
out. In other words, I informed him that a panacea for
the prevention of malaria, if generally accepted as ade-
quate, would prevent appropriation of funds and retard
antimalarial work.

Mr. Rose was informed that it was the desire of the
Surgeon General to arrange for cooperative work, and it was
-4-
tentatively suggested that this cooperation might consist
on the part of the Commission in the detail of its offi-
cers to work under the direction of experienced officers
of the Public Health Service and in the furnishing of funds
for expenses in local communities selected, which expenses
the Public Health Service was not in position to defray.
This seemed agreeable to Mr. Rose, who expressed a desire
that a conference be arranged which would be attended by
our field officers and by the Surgeon General or a repre-
sentative of his office, and a representative of the Inter-
national Health Commission. He stated that he could attend
such a conference in Washington or in the South any time be-
tween the 20th and 30th of September.

It is evident that Mr. Rose is being urged to commit
the International Health Commission to antimalarial demon-
stration work. He has apparently made up his mind to fi-
nance a demonstration under the supervision of Dr. Bass,
and would willingly recommend to the Commission the financ-
ing of cooperative work with the Public Health Service.
